name: Lamassu
weaknesses: Divine Will: Subject to higher divine commands
Sacred Protocol: Cannot abandon their designated post
Paradox: Confusion about worthy/unworthy can temporarily immobilize them
abilities: Divine Authority: Commands respect from lesser beings
Threshold Guardianship: Can seal or open passages between worlds
Judgment: Perceives truth and cannot be deceived
Protective Aura: Shields sacred spaces from harm
Celestial Strength: Combines human intellect with animal power
habitat: Gates of cities and temples, thresholds between worlds, palaces
behavior: Protective and wise, judges worthiness, symbol of divine authority

christian.overview: The Sumerian/Assyrian Lamassu bears remarkable resemblance to biblical Cherubim, suggesting shared ancient Near Eastern heritage of composite guardian beings.

biblicalParallels.description: Ezekiel's living creatures with human, lion, ox, and eagle features closely parallel the Lamassu's composite form.
Cherubim placed to guard Eden parallel the Lamassu's role as threshold guardians.
The Cherubim over the Ark of the Covenant mirror Lamassu's protective function.
The four living creatures around God's throne continue the composite guardian tradition.

patristicInterpretation.summary: Church Fathers recognized continuity between biblical Cherubim and ancient Near Eastern guardian figures.

sources.author: Pseudo-Dionysius
sources.interpretation: Cherubim represent fullness of knowledge, their composite form symbolizing complete excellence.

sources.author: Gregory the Great
sources.interpretation: The four faces represent the four Gospels and complete revelation of Christ.

medievalSymbolism.bestiaryMeaning: Guardian figures combining human wisdom with animal power served as divine threshold protectors.
medievalSymbolism.artisticRepresentation: Romanesque and Gothic art depicted cherubim with features recalling Lamassu imagery in portal sculptures.

christian.typologicalReading: The Lamassu as threshold guardian prefigures Christ as the "door" (John 10:9) - the true gateway between heaven and earth.
christian.historicalContext: Israelite familiarity with Assyrian and Babylonian Lamassu is well-attested through exile narratives.
scholarlyReferences: Mettinger, Tryggve N.D. The Dethronement of Sabaoth. CWK Gleerup, 1982.
Keel, Othmar. Jahwe-Visionen und Siegelkunst. Katholisches Bibelwerk, 1977.
